header.title: Sticks, Stones, Roots & Bones: Hoodoo, Mojo & Conjuring with Herbs
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Folk Magic, Hoodoo

central_thesis: The central thesis of the book is that Hoodoo is an eclectic, natural, nondogmatic, and practical system of African-based folk magic. It emphasizes self-determination, connection to nature, awareness of the environment, and ancestral connection, integrating African, Native American, Judeo-Christian, and European influences. The book serves as a practical guide to practicing this tradition using natural elements and rituals to achieve health, wealth, love, luck, and happiness.

structure_content.summary: This chapter explores the origins of Hoodoo in the Americas, detailing its multicultural nature and practical focus on health, wealth, love, luck, and happiness. It introduces key concepts like 'laying of tricks' and 'fixing tricks' using 'mojo bags' and various herb-based oils, incenses, and salts, and touches upon divination methods and the importance of ancestral/natural spirits, emphasizing self-determination over commercialization.

This section highlights the critical importance of respecting Mother Nature as the source of Hoodoo's essential tools (sticks, stones, roots, bones). It emphasizes working in harmony with nature, ethical harvesting (especially for endangered plants), and introduces animistic philosophy as a fundamental aspect of Hoodoo practice.

This chapter delves into the practical aspects of rootwork, underscoring the need for patience and a clean, organized workspace. It discusses the historical shift from homemade Hoodoo products to inferior commercial blends, advocating for the use of authentic ingredients, and lists essential equipment and tools for preparing herbal brews, oils, and soaps.

This chapter defines 'mojo' as a bag of charms, correcting popular misconceptions about its sexual connotations. It introduces the African concept of 'ashe' (invisible power of nature) and 'nkisi' (Kongo power figures/charms), discusses the practice of feeding mojo bags, and provides practical recipes for various mojo types like 'Fast Luck Mojo', 'Money Draw Mojo', 'Stay Away From Me Mojo', 'Peaceful Hand', 'Attraction Mojo', 'Unhex Mojo', and 'Love Draw Nation Sack'.

This chapter explores the profound spiritual significance of brooms in African and African American folklore, tracing its uses from ancient Africa (involving sorghum, raffia, Oya, Nana Buku) to traditional African American weddings (jumping the broom). It discusses broom etiquette, its role as a tool for healing and protection, broom spirits, and provides rituals such as the 'Magickal Whisk Broom' and a 'Jumping Broom' recipe.

This chapter focuses on 'foot track magick' and spiritual cleansing of both home and body to banish negative energy. It discusses the sacredness of salt in various cultures and its use in purification. Practical guidance includes a 'House Cleaning Ritual' (smudging, dusting solutions, ceremonial dirt disposal) and recipes for 'Healing Bath Crystals', 'Spirit Renewal Bath Sachet', various soaps ('Soul Heal Soap', 'Angels on High Soap'), body oils ('Strengthening Body Oil'), powders ('Commanding Powder', 'High Road Powder'), and fragrant waters ('De-Stressing Floral Water', 'Florida Water', 'Rose Water', 'Body Perfume').

This chapter explores the element of fire and the use of candles in Hoodoo rituals, particularly in relation to holidays and ancestral veneration. It covers 'Candlemancy' and the symbolic meanings of various candle colors for different purposes (white, yellow, orange, red, pink, purple, blue, green, brown, black). It details how to 'anointin' and dressin' candles' with oils and herbs, introduces the 'Conjuring Altar' as a sacred space, discusses 'Disposal of Candle Wax', and presents a 'Kinnikinnik' offering ritual.

This chapter examines the 'warrior' aspects of Hoodoo, drawing parallels with African hunters and sorcerers. Key concepts include 'nyama' (unpredictable energy) and 'jiridon' (the science of trees). It details 'Foot Track Magick' using various powders ('Gopher's Dust', 'Hot Foot Powder', 'Stay Away Powder', 'Warrior's Path Powder') and other obstructions to repel enemies, emphasizing ethical use and protection. The chapter also discusses Ogun (warrior orisha), Oya (orisha of wind/changes) and their invocations, and 'Four Thieves Vinegar' and 'War Water Bottles' as powerful deterrents.

This chapter highlights water as an element for peace, calming, and protection. It discusses water orishas like Yemoya-Olokun, Oshun, and Erinle. Recipes provided include 'Water Orisha's Sweet Water Wash', 'Sacred Space Ritual', and 'Peace Oil', along with various floral and sweet waters. It emphasizes the importance of silver and turquoise for protection and explores 'Dirt and Minerals' and 'Mud Play' for grounding and stability.

This chapter outlines methods for attracting money, luck, and prosperity. It discusses 'Growin' Green' herbs, offerings to ancestral spirits, and the use of charged lodestones. Specific charms like 'Clover Charm' and 'High John Charm' are detailed. The chapter also covers 'Money-Drawing Fires', 'Horseshoes and Nails' for binding intentions, 'Lucky Hand Washes', 'Lucky Hand Rub', 'Devil's Shoestring Rub', 'Money-Drawing Floor Wash', and 'Money Jars' and 'Money Egg'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Gettin' Some Love & Keepin' It Close
structure_content.summary: Dedicated to love magic, this chapter covers attraction and fidelity. It includes instructions for creating 'Love Mojo' bags with lodestones and explores 'Aromatherapy for Hoodoo Love Draw' using herbs like lavender, lotus, mandrake, myrtle, vanilla, violet, willow, cinnamon, cloves, nutmeg, and orange. Practical recipes include 'Love Fruit Pomander', 'Love-Drawing Incense', 'Sunkissed Love Draw Tips', 'Spirit of Love Floor Wash', 'Love Beads', 'Passion Garland', 'Love Potion', 'Love Bud Lip Smacker', and 'Passion Oil'.

This chapter addresses fertility rituals and preparations for pregnancy and childbirth. It discusses the role of water in pregnancy, highlights various goddesses of fertility (Memu, Odudua, Corn Ma, Selu), and explores specific herbs like dandelion, raspberry leaf, burdock root, nettle, and oats for their medicinal and magical properties. Recipes include 'Prenuptial Shampoo', 'After-Birth Healing Compresses', 'After-Birth Herbal Sitz Bath', 'Nefertiti's Milk Bath', and 'Apres De Bain Foreplay Oil'.

Continuing from the fertility theme, this chapter focuses on the Hoodoo child's life stages from birth to adulthood. It discusses naming ceremonies, protective measures for children, and rites of passage. Practical applications include recipes for 'Welcome Little Spirit Incense Blend' and 'Spirit Wash' for the nursery or family bedroom.

This chapter delves into dreamwork, divination, and protection against spiritual attacks during sleep. It explores the concept of the 'witching hour' and techniques like 'scrying' for clarity. It provides a 'Warrior's Trick Workshop' involving meditation, visualization, and a 'Dream Pillow' recipe. Mythic goddesses who inform dreams (Isis, Inanna, Gaia, Geb) and the ancient Egyptian incense 'Kyphi' are discussed, along with an 'Isis Dream Ritual'.

This chapter examines African American attitudes toward grief, mourning, and burial rituals. It discusses the concept of animism and the profound importance of ancestors. It explores the 'jazz funeral' tradition and offers ways to honor departed spirits, including offerings and specific burial customs. Practical rituals include 'On With Life! Bath Ritual', 'Release Incense', and 'Funerary Wreath'.

key_concepts.definition: An eclectic, natural, nondogmatic, and practical system of African-based folk magic, primarily focused on health, wealth, love, luck, and happiness. It integrates African, Native American, Judeo-Christian, and European influences.
Another name for Hoodoo, focusing on understanding herbalism and incorporating indigenous wisdom regarding nature for magical and medicinal purposes.

A small bag of charms that serves as an amulet for various purposes, such as attracting a lover, maintaining a relationship, drawing luck, or money. It contains personalized items and carries personal energy.
The invisible power of nature, present in herbal products and natural objects, believed to be the source of medicinal and magical powers.

Kongo power figures or charms, powered by nature spirits, containing various natural materials (seashells, feathers, nuts, berries, stones, bones, leaves, roots, twigs) to help people heal and serve as safe spots for the soul.

The West African science of trees, learned directly from trees and plants through observation, practiced by hunters, warriors, and shamans. Masters of Jiridon are master herbalists and adept ecologists.
A magical element of Hoodoo that involves using dirt from physical tracks and footprints of humans or animals for specific jobs, often to influence or bind individuals.
The art of using candles magically, incorporating specific colors and dressings (oils, herbs) to add intent and energy to rituals.

An Afro-Brazilian leaf-whipping practice using bundles of leaves and twigs as a makeshift broom to purge evil spirits and bad influences, restoring balance and harmony. (Also, in a colloquial sense, a 'switch-whippin'' on the backside for children.)

A symbol from Kongo cosmology resembling a crossroads, representing the intersection of the world of the living and the dead, and the center of the four winds. It is sacred ground suitable for oath-taking or making agreements.
Ancient Egyptian term for the shadow or spirit self, which may get thirsty and wander dangerously distant from the body during sleep, potentially leading to a catatonic state.
An ancient Egyptian incense used for divination, dreamwork, and creating a sacred, healing, and loving environment, originally called 'kapet' or 'kupar' for fumigation.
A Yoruban term for an herb or plant that corresponds to a specific Orisha, embodying medicinal and magical powers.
The practice of applying herb-infused oils to candles to add extra strength, intent, and energy, transforming them from mundane objects to magically charged tools for 'jobs and tricks'.

A specific type of mojo bag, strictly 'women's business', used primarily for protection for women and children, and sometimes for drawing love. It is full of Africanisms and stems from West African secret women's societies.

practical_system.description: The book presents a practical, hands-on system for practicing Hoodoo, referred to as 'rootwork' or 'conjur craft.' This system emphasizes a DIY approach, ethical sourcing of natural materials, and the practitioner's intent and personal energy ('ashe') in creating customized magical tools and preparations for various life concerns. It integrates African animistic philosophy, European magical traditions, and Native American herbal wisdom.

relevant_quotes.text: Sticks, stones, roots, and bones—these are the basic ingredients found in any good hoodoo's mojo bag.
Now keep your hands off a' my mojo, 'cause it sure is lucky to me
Metals are the "flesh of the gods and goddesses," the bones of the Earth, manifestations of universal powers.

The Negro's terror of a broom is of very ancient date—it may have an African origin. It was commented upon by Moreau de Saint-Mery in his work on San Domingo, published in 1796. 'What especially irritates the Negro,' he wrote, 'is to have a broom passed over any part of his body. He asks at once whether the person imagined that he was dead, and remains convinced that the act shortens his life.' ... 'If you are pestered by visitors whom you would wish never to see again, sprinkle salt on the floor after they go, and sweep it out by the same door through which they have gone and they will never come back.'
I've known rivers: I've known rivers ancient as the world and older than the flow of human blood in human veins. My soul has grown deep like the rivers.
If we don't allow greed to overwhelm us, it is easy to identify with the wisdom of the ancient Egyptians. Quite simply, luck is to have a long, healthy, and vigorous life.

critical_analysis.relevance: The book offers a comprehensive, practical, and culturally nuanced guide to Hoodoo, emphasizing its African roots and multicultural influences. It demystifies practices often misrepresented (e.g., mojo, voodoo) and promotes ethical engagement with natural materials and spirits. Its focus on self-determination, personal empowerment, and practical life concerns (health, wealth, love, luck, happiness) makes it highly relevant for contemporary practitioners seeking connection, healing, and personal development within a folk magic framework.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes practitioners of Hoodoo, rootwork, and other forms of folk magic; individuals interested in African American spirituality, herbalism, and ancestral veneration; those seeking practical magical techniques for personal development, healing, prosperity, and love; and academics studying cultural folklore and esotericism. The book is inclusive, catering to both novices and more experienced practitioners, and those interested in a DIY approach to magic and self-empowerment.
